Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Low-Dimensional Spin Systems: Interplay of Chemical Pressure on Triangular Lattices with Spin- and Orbital Degrees of Freedom
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
The objective of this CAREER proposal, supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry (SSMC) program, is to understand the effects of chemical pressure on geometrically frustrated lattices in the presence of spin and orbital degrees of freedom. A recently identified and subsequently synthesized new series of compounds exhibiting a triangular lattice of magnetic ions confined in a robust two-dimensional building block has emerged as a suitable template to investigate: (1) the impact of induced slight structural distortions and (2) the dependence of the magnetic correlations on the respective spin system. A unique opportunity to derive insights into tuning ferromagnetic and anti-ferromagnetic correlations mediated through super-exchange pathways has emerged for this series of compounds. The investigations are mainly experimental and encompass solid state chemistry synthesis, spectroscopy, magnetization, and specific heat measurements. The scientific impact of this work will contribute to a fundamental understanding of phenomena occurring on geometrically frustrated systems, including aspects of spin-orbit coupling for divalent and trivalent 3d transition metal cations. Furthermore, the discovery of new members of the highly unique class of ferromagnetic insulators represents an additional exciting advance and an important contribution to the field of multifunctional materials.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
Advances in the field of next-generation materials with relevance to energy and sensors rely on the development of a fundamental understanding of the properties of materials. Further, the design of new classes of materials and the ability to control important functional parameters of these materials require a detailed understanding of the mechanisms at work. To this end, the conceptual framework underlying the proposed research activities, supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program (SSMC), seeks to establish the fundamental structure-property relationships that define the behavior and utility of new classes of functional materials. For example, recent discoveries in our laboratory demonstrate our ability to tune the magnetic properties of a novel series of insulators; these materials should ultimately find use as magnetoresistive sensors for global positioning/navigation in remote areas. In conjunction with these activities, the proposed educational activities seek to provide training in the interdisciplinary areas of solid state chemistry and condensed matter physics for both undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Houston, which is ranked second among the country's most diverse universities. The PI has established mentoring and volunteer programs from elementary to K-12 levels at schools within the Houston Independent School District. These programs communicate fundamental materials science geared toward understanding scientific aspects of everyday life in experiments and lectures to raise awareness and fascination for next-generation challenges. Furthermore, the PI's activities aim to promote materials science, encompass interaction with young scientists at large, and include international collaborations with highly regarded institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In order to continuously improve the performance of devices and technologies in everyday use, development of novel materials is essential. In this context the training of next-generation chemists in elaborated synthesis methods remains an important aspect. Another essential feature is the collaboration with physics and theory, which accelerates a detailed understanding of the delicate interplay between specific control parameters and will eventually contribute to close gaps in our current knowledge.

The fundamental interdisciplinary research carried out under this award was designed to specifically synthesize model compounds via solid state chemistry routes. Additional characterization of the magnetic and spectroscopic properties were essential in the study of the inherent magnetic order. Thereby, valuable information of the delicate tunability of specific magnetic scenarios was gained. The chosen degrees of freedom were: (i) the crystal structure symmetry as a function of external or chemical pressure, and (ii) the inherent magnetic single ion properties referred to as the ‘spin’ or the ‘spin-orbital’ coupling.

The key outcome of this experimental research are in-depth insights for a rationally designed class of ‘geometrically frustrated’ materials and a variety of derivatives including honeycomb and kagome lattices. These low-dimensional materials stand out because of their rather unusual properties and the distinct features assessed by theory. Through a chemically controlled synthesis a series of model compounds with specific magnetic exchange pathways via hybridization were made available. The detailed structure-property relationship study lead to the discovery of examples for rare magnetic states: ferromagnetic insulators, chiral and incommensurate antiferromagnets, and spin-liquid like compounds. Significant results of this research are the model compounds with tunable competing interactions beyond geometrical aspects. These may serve as reference materials for the theoretical treatment of the two most interesting cases: chirality and entanglement. Both aspects are currently of major research activities and might be crucial to develop next generation materials beyond classical energy conversion technologies. Additionally, the successful outcome of this research was made possible by beamline support through the Oak-Ridge National Laboratory user facility.       

Involved in this research activities were four graduate and five undergraduate students, mostly underrepresented minorities in the STEM disciplines. Beyond the hands-on training of students in the laboratory and peer-reviewed publications, all graduate students and one undergraduate student presented their projects at national conference meetings. Additionally, the graduate students and PI were engaged in numerous public outreach programs for underrepresented students in the STEM field and served at general science fares.
